awd_titl_txt: Microcirculatory blood flow in sickle cell disease
awd_abstract_narration:
Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a disorder of red blood cells that affects about 100,000 Americans, particularly those whose ancestors came from sub-Saharan Africa or Latin America. In the disorder, red blood cells stiffen as they age and often take on a sickle shape. Acute symptoms of SCD arise when diseased red blood cells obstruct small blood vessels due to the sickled shape and increased stiffness, resulting in restricted local blood flow.  However, chronic issues arise as well, and these have received less attention in the past. The cells that line blood vessels become dysfunctional in most regions of the circulation, and especially in the brain, where blood vessel damage is associated with increased risk of stroke, one of the leading yet least understood causes of mortality in SCD. Additionally, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that having SCD increases the risk of severe illness from COVID-19. This project will use simulations of a detailed mathematical model of blood flow to gain a better understanding of how the altered properties of sickle cells may lead to damage of blood vessel walls. Particular attention will be paid to blood vessels of serpentine and related shapes that are found in the brain.   

Diseased cells of a SCD patient are smaller and stiffer than healthy red blood cells (RBCs). Both of these features increase the propensity for cells to reside near blood vessel walls, a phenomenon called margination. Past experimental and computational work in idealized systems supports the hypothesis that diseased cells strongly marginate, residing primarily in the cell-free layer near blood vessel walls, thereby generating physical interactions such as large shear stress fluctuations and mechanical contacts that damage the endothelial cells that line the vessels. This project will move from idealized systems to physiologically relevant conditions and complexities, addressing important questions about the fluid mechanics of sickle cell disease. Detailed simulations and simplified mechanistic models will be used to (1) Predict the effects of cell properties, including shape, size, stiffness, adhesiveness and polydispersity on spatial distributions and wall interactions during flow, and (2)  Mechanistically determine the effects of blood vessel geometry and hemodynamics on SCD RBC margination and cell-wall interactions, particularly in branched and serpentine blood vessel geometries characteristic of the brain microcirculation.  Broader impacts of the project include (1) its focus on connecting fundamental biomechanics and fluid dynamics to an important problem in medicine, (2) involvement of undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented minorities, in research, and (3) a service learning course in which undergraduate engineering students develop project-based lessons in fluid mechanics and share them with children from underserved minority populations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Red blood cell (RBC) physical properties and interactions have long been observed to be altered in disease. In some cases, such as sickle cell disease (SCD),  the RBC changes are at the origin of the disorder.However, in many diseases, while the cause of the disease may not originate with changes in RBCs, such changes may play  a key role in its progress and severity.  The overarching aim of work performed under this grant is to study, with simulations and theory guided by the hematological and clinical expertise of our collaborators, fluid mechanical phenomena associated with changes to blood that arise in a range of diseases.
RBC physical properties and interactions that have been observed to change in a range of disorders include size, shape, stiffness, and degree of aggregation. An important effect that is observed in a variety of disorders is that the endothelial cells lining the blood vessels are dysfunctional. This is associated, for example, in COVID, sepsis, sickle cell disease and iron deficiency anemia, with substantially increased risk of stroke and other serious circulatory problems.  The origin of this dysfunction is unclear, and we hypothesize that it is connected with the changes in RBC properties and interactions, which in turn affect how the RBCs interact with the blood vessel walls.  Simulations of a detailed computational model of blood flow reveal that RBCs that are small and/or stiffer than the healthy cells tend to be driven toward blood vessel walls, a phenomenon called margination.  In a curved channel exemplifying the geometric complexity of the microcirculation, these cells distribute heterogeneously, indicating the importance of geometry. Marginated cells generate large transient stress fluctuations on vessel walls, indicating a mechanism for the observed vascular inflammation. The computational studies performed under this grant are consistent with the experimental observations of our collaborator Wilbur Lam's group using microfluidic models of blood flow  in sickle cell disease and iron deficiency anemia. 
Aberrant RBC aggregation has also been observed to be associated with  endothelial damage in disorders including COVID and sepsis, but the underlying biophysical mechanisms remain unclear. We have used  direct computational modeling to explore how red blood cell (RBC) aggregation impacts shear stress in small blood vessels, highlighting the increased risk of vascular damage. RBC aggregation creates a heterogeneous distribution, leading to variations in the cell-free layer thickness and fluctuating wall shear stress, especially near vessel walls. This effect aligns with experimental findings on endothelial disruption linked to RBC clustering near the wall.  The presence of aberrant cells in blood disorders, modeled here as sickle cells, further amplifies these effects, as aggregation-enhanced margination drives sickle cells closer to vessel walls, exacerbating shear stress fluctuations and increasing the likelihood of vascular injury and inflammation. Simulations show that curved vascular geometry, with curvature accentuating RBC clustering near vessel walls, intensifies aggregation-induced wall shear stress fluctuations and increases the risk of vascular damage, particularly in sickle cell disease where sickle cells marginate closer to the wall.


Last Modified: 03/09/2025
Modified by: Michael D Graham

Image
  • Simulation snapshots of blood flow in models of (A) sickle cell disease, (B) iron deficiency anemia, (C) COVID, (D) spherocytosis. Aberrant red blood cells are shown in blue.
    Xiaopo Cheng and Michael D. Graham
    Copyrighted
    Michael D Graham
    BloodFlow-disorders
